awd_titl_txt: INFEWS N/P/H20: Nitrogen and Phosphorus Dynamics in Restored Floodplains of Intensively Managed Watersheds
awd_abstract_narration:
1706612 (McMillan). Excess nitrogen and phosphorus in receiving waters (streams, rivers, lakes, etc.) is associated with high nutrient inputs (e.g., fertilizer, food and animal waste, sewage overflows) in watersheds that are unsustainably and intensively managed for agriculture and urban uses. Sustainably restoring floodplains shows great promise to improve water quality and multiple ecosystem (e.g., floodplain soils) services, however a clear understanding and quantification of the cumulative effects of inundation on nitrogen and phosphorus dynamics is critically needed. Therefore, the goal of this research is to determine the functional relationships that exist between sources and sinks of nutrients (e.g., denitrification, phosphorus release) and natural system drivers (e.g., hydrodynamic and biogeochemical). 

To achieve this goal, this project seeks to (1) quantify how hydrologic connectivity varies across spatial and temporal scales in a river floodplain system, (2) characterize the relative role of hydrodynamic versus biogeochemical processes on the rates of nitrogen and phosphorus inputs, removal and release in floodplain soils, and (3) determine the cumulative effect on the retention or release of nitrogen and phosphorus at the river-floodplain system scale. The research will consist of three major components to link physical and biogeochemical controls of nitrogen and phosphorus dynamics in restored riverine floodplains. The first component will apply a 2-dimensional model of the Wabash-Tippecanoe River confluence to predict the time and lateral extent of inundation as well as magnitude and direction of surface velocity and groundwater flow to quantify hydraulic residence time and lateral water flux. The second component will quantify key processes responsible for nutrient flux in the floodplain system, including nitrogen removal via denitrification, phosphorus uptake/release, and the soil properties that could help predict these processes. Nitrogen and phosphorus response variables and potential predictors variables will be linked in the third component to identify the controls on processes using a multivariate statistical approach. A systems analysis approach will be used to apply these relationships to aggregate fluxes at the monthly scale and determine net floodplain function (e.g., source/sink behavior). Through this research, critical information will be provided that is needed to sustainably restore floodplain ecosystems that maximize water quality improvements for both nitrogen and phosphorus. Impacts of this research are potentially far-reaching as communities and regulatory agencies invest in mitigation projects to reduce nutrient loads to downstream lakes and coastal zones where eutrophication impacts are occurring.

por.por_cntn:
Nature-based solutions such as floodplain and wetland restoration are needed to create climate-resilient landscapes. Our research improved understanding of the water quality functions of restored floodplains, particularly related to nitrogen and phosphorus. We conducted our research at the confluence of the Wabash and Tippecanoe Rivers in Indiana, USA in four floodplains with diverse land management, including conventional row crop agriculture, two restored prairie floodplains, and a restored floodplain with ephemeral channels and depressional wetlands. We found that the restoration approach and land management were the dominant drivers of soil properties and water quality outcomes, more so than modeled flood frequency or velocity. Experimental work coupled with machine learning models showed that denitrification capacity was most strongly influenced by soil carbon and vegetation and that rates were highest in the winter, when nitrate in rivers draining agricultural watersheds is also highest. Conventional row-crop agriculture consistently had the lowest rates of denitrification in soils with low organic carbon compared to the other restored sites. We also found that denitrification rates were highest near the soil surface and decreased with depth where organic carbon is scarce. We replicated flooding conditions on floodplains in the laboratory and found an optimal flood duration of 4-8 days to minimize pollutant swapping. During initial flooding (days 1-4), N was removed via denitrification and P stored in the soil was generally not released to the water column. However, a transition developed around 8 days when oxygen was depleted by microbial metabolism and labile P was released. This shows the importance of flood duration, the amount and type of P stored in soils, and the magnitudes of both nutrients in floodwaters. We also showed that freezing and flooding interact to release more P when soils were previously frozen. 

We connected this experimental work with river-floodplain models that spanned a range of complexities. This approach was taken to characterize the computational resources and knowledge/expertise needed to estimate flood properties that affect water quality with appropriate levels of certainty. We found that the most detailed model (ICPR) represented fine-scale features of topography and led to better predictions of flood water velocity and groundwater table depth. However, it is computationally expensive, limited to short term simulations, and requires highly skilled operation. HEC-RAS 2D, which is widely used by practitioners, was well suited to capturing surface water and flood dynamics when run over longer simulation periods. It also created visualizations of complex flow paths that were an important tool in sharing results with diverse audiences. We then used these models to generate metrics on expected flood frequency and degree of connection with the river. These metrics were combined with results of our experimental work to see if we could better predict water quality outcomes. We found that connectivity between flood waters and biological active floodplain soils is driven by elevation of the floodplain and access (such as lowered banks or targeted levee removal) and that many soil properties such as texture and organic matter are a function of this degree of connection. But, it was the local soil properties (texture, carbon) and the type of vegetation that most directly influenced rates of denitrification. Flood duration during an event, rather than distance to the river or long-term flood frequency, was the most important factor driving dissolved reactive P release from soils. It?s important to remember that this work focused on soil processes and future work will focus on a system-wide mass balance to account for deposition of P attached to suspended sediment from the river. 

This work highlighted the importance of land management in floodplains. We observed positive water quality outcomes in restored floodplains with depressional wetlands and prairie vegetation that also had the highest connectivity and soil organic carbon.In contrast, we showed the lowest water quality benefits in conventional row crop agriculture. Restoration designs and management approaches are needed to conserve and store additional soil carbon and promote delivery of N to carbon-enriched soils. Creating restorations that support multiple periods of short duration flooding will help achieve N reduction goals while trapping and keeping P stored in floodplain sediments. Our results have implications for floodplain restoration throughout the Midwest and beyond with impacts on policy making in Indiana and watersheds draining to the Chesapeake Bay.
